message_1: A student wants to form a committee of 4 people from a group of 7 students. How many different committees can they form?
message_2:
To find the number of different committees that can be formed, we need to use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of students (7 in this case), k is the number of students in the committee (4 in this case), and ! denotes the factorial function (e.g., 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1).

So, we have:

C(7, 4) = 7! / (4!(7-4)!)

C(7, 4) = 7! / (4!3!)

C(7, 4) = (7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((4 × 3 × 2 × 1)(3 × 2 × 1))

C(7, 4) = (7 × 6 × 5) / (4 × 3 × 2 × 1)

C(7, 4) = 210 / 24

C(7, 4) = 35

So, there are 35 different committees that can be formed from a group of 7 students.
